description.text: Just a simple little desk organizer.

Replacement for the allways breaking lids of the hanging spice rack in our kitchen. I'm not totally satisfied with the thread, but it works. If someone improves it, I would like to know. EMSA compatible. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/bbweEcVxedz

put it upside down like on the foto and screenshot so there are no supports needed. Because the bending stress is quite high I put two on a big rim and fixed the middle with Tesa. Printing only one resulted in breaking the lid off the brim. This is PLA, 215°C on the lower parts, 210°C and SLOWER when the thread is printed. 28% infill. Took six hours on a Vertex 8400
Ripping someone off, do you know who?
Recommend you look for some cheap "pirate" gems to go with it.

title: Evil Dragon Head Trophy
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
After printing the awesome dragon head trophy and mounting it on my bot, I realized that there was just one thing missing: LEDs. A small amount of drilling and some soldering later, and the dragon head was alive and well.
Then it turned it's head to stare at me with its cold, unblinking eyes, and started making a low growling noise.
Uh oh, that can't be a good sign...

You will need:
  • Dragon head trophy print
  • 2x small (3mm) LED
  • 2x 100 ohm (or so)
  • some thin wires (I pulled some from a discarded USB cable)
  • Drill with bits
  • Soldering iron
    • Drill a big hole through the back of the dragons head up to it's snout, roughly where it's throat would be if it were a real dragon. Drill two smaller holes through the eye sockets, so that they end in the big throat hole. Fish two small wires through each eye socket and out the back, attach LEDs to the front, then pull the LEDs into the dragon's head so that they look like eyes. On the other end of the wires, solder a resistor in series with each led, and hook each up to a 5v line (I used a servo connector on my extruder board). Alternatively, you could add some alternative plumbing to the model so that no drilling is necessary :-).

title: prusa i3 direct drive extruder for e3d hotend and mk8 drive gear

description.text:
This is a direct drive extruder for the E3D v6 and MK8 drive gear, fitting directly on the x carriage. Read below what other goals have been considered in the design. Along with the switch to an e3d hotend i also wanted to upgrade to a direct drive extruder. Unfortunately none of the designs i could find on thingiverse suited all of my needs completely, so i decided to make my own. I am coming from a JHead paired with Gregs extruder. So this is my version of a direct drive extruder meeting the following goals:
  • no bowden design
  • extruder should not narrow the build volume (with my old extruder the motor hit a bracket, limiting the z height)
  • weight balanced design (should not "fall forward", of course the success is limited by the clearance the motor has to the frame)
  • symmetrical design to ease fan mouting
  • cable management (optional)
  • flag for optical endstop (optional, this one here)
  • mk8 drive gear
  • suitable for E3D v6 1.75mm, therefore the extruder should have a 4mm bore so that the PTFE tubing of the E3D can be extended into the extruder, just below the drive gear
  • attachable to a x carriage with 30mm hole distance
  • a little bit more rigid than other designs ;-)
    • An optional fan duct fitting this design is available here. The extruder design was vaguely inspired by the Hackerbot direct drive extruder.

• DDExtruder
  • DDIdler
  • MountingPlate
  • HotEndBracket

• 1x MK8 drive gear for 1.75mm filament
  • 1x MR105ZZ bearing (5x10x4)
  • 1x M4x50 screws
  • 4x M4x30 screws
  • 5x M4 nuts
  • a spring for the idler
  • a few M4 washers (optional, use to increase tension on the idler if your spring is to weak, or try to use a shorter screw)
  • 1x M3x16 screw
  • 1x M3x20 screw
  • 1x M3 nut
  • 2x M3 washers
  • 3x M3x10 screws
    • and of course an E3D v6 and some PTFE tubing

• CableBracket:
    replace 2x M3x10 by 2x M3x20 screws
    some zipties
  • BearingExtender:
    1x MR105ZZ bearing

• print everything with 0.2mm layer height (or 0.1mm, but thats overkill) to not mess up the item heights. You should not need additional support as all needed support is included (you need to rotate some things prior to printing)
  • remove support material
    • MountPlate: break the 4 pillars free from the M4 nut shafts. Remove the support at the flag for the optical endstop (about 2mm) or break the whole flag off if you do not want it.
    • DDIdler: remove the support so that you can clip the idler later into the extruder
    • DDExtruder: the support is a little bit hard to see. You must remove support on the top right corner, there where the idler is supposed to go later.
  • put everything together
    • DDIdler: Put the bearing on the the shaft, then put two M3 washers onto the M3x16 screw and screw it into the shaft. Secure the bearing on the other side with a M3 nut. This gives the shaft extra rigidity. The two washers are required to get the clearance to the DDExtruder right.
    • DDExtruder: Put the DDIdler into the extruder. Move it a few times to make sure it can move freely. Use the M3x20 screw for attaching the extruder to your motor while also holding the idler in place. Use 3 M3x10 screws for the remaining screwholes. Insert the Mk8 drive gear and line it up with the filament bores. Do not assemble the M4x50 screw and the spring until you really want to put filament into the extruder.
    • MountingPlate: Put the M4 nuts into the 4 holes. Attach the DDExtruder with 2 M4 screws to the mountplate. Take your E3D hotend, put the PTFE liner into it and hold it into its place on the moutning plate, so that you can measure the required length of the PTFE liner. The liner is supposed to be extended into the extruder and reach right below the MK8 drive gear. If you have cut your liner to the right length, insert the liner into the extruder, press the hotend into place and secure it with HotEndBracket and 2 M4 screws.
  • attach the extruder to your x carriage.

• If you want to use the cable management bracket simply print 2 of them and scew them into place using 2 M3x20 screws instead of 2 M3x10 screws. Use the zipties to tie the cables to the brackets.
  • If you do not trust the little shaft (of rather the bearing of the stepper) to withstand the load applied from the idler, print the BearingExtender, put an additional MR105ZZ bearing into it, push the whole thing onto the motor shaft and clip it into the corresponding place in the extruder.

title: Sample Filament Rack for Printrbot Simple Metal

description.text:
I had a bunch of filament sample rolls I got from Amazon and got tired of filament bunching up and ruining prints so I made this simple free-hanging filament holder. Does not actually attach to z-posts, just rests on top of. My print came out to just .010 larger, so the fit is really nice. The spool is snug into the fixture with a flat key to not roll around. title: Adjustable e3d v6 mount for Vertex K8400

description.text: This thing is to mount a pair of e3d V6 hotends on a Vertex K8400 The design is rigid, results in no loss of travel on the y and z axes and allows for precise adjustment of the height of the two hotends.

Print out the parts, no support is required. Remove the existing hot ends and top fan (which you will not be using).  Replace the 10 ohm resistor on the extruder board with an 80 ohm one to ensure the small fan is only supplied with 12 volts. Drop the infill parts into the top 'xy carriage 2' and fit the mount you have made. you will need to replace the four existing m3 screws with ones that are 60mm long.  
Insert the four m3 adjusting screws and screw them down until they are in contact with the infill parts you printed. Fit the extruders and refit the small fan with the duct.  
Spend some time ensuring that you bed is level. Go to the home position and then move the hotend to the centre of the print area and measure the gap between each nozzle and the bed. Precisely measure with feeler gauges the heights of the two nozzles.  
Depending upon the pitch of the m3 adjusting screws that you have used calculate how many degrees the ones on the nozzle that is lower need the be turned to raise that side to the same level as the other one.  For example, it is most likely that the pitch of the m3 screws will be 0.5mm so if you find a height difference of 0.15mm then that requires the screws to be turned 108 degrees.  
To make this adjustment lower the bed and slacken of the four 60mm screws  holding the print head assembly together by a couple of turns, and turn the two adjusting screws on the low side by the appropriate number of degrees. Tighten the two 60mm assembly screws on the opposite side to that which you have raised and then tighten the ones on the side you have raised. Finally go to the home position, move the hotend to the centre of the print area and measure the gap between each nozzle. Hopefully you will find them to be level, but if not repeat the adjustment procedure above.  
To make this adjustment easier and to allow you to do it without lowering the print bed to gain access to the four nuts holding the print assembly together, I have added an stl file of a modifird bottom piece of xy2 carriage supports.  The only modifications are to inset the hexagon for the 3mm lock nuts and to  create a wider rim at the bottom to reinforce the walls of the hexagon. To fit this piece you merely have to remove the four nuts holding the assembly and replace the existing bottom xy2 carriage block with the one you have printed. Now when you come to make your adjustment you can do it all from the top of the print assembly.  
When printing all of these parts I find that a one point five percent increase in scale results in object that are identical in dimension to the original drawings  
Ammendment  
The original file I submitted called 'short hot end with level screws' had the hole to give access to the hexagon that holds the middle nut at the bottom when it should have been at the top. It will still work but there is a danger that the nut may be pushed out making it difficult to tighten the middle screw. I should have loaded the revised file ''short hot end with level screws2'  This has the hole at the top and is 1mm longer to increase the distance from the hotend to the bottom of the xy2 revised carriage block that  I previously posted. When you print this part I suggest you turn it upside down so that the four hexagon recesses are at the top

title: dual 40mm fan duct for direct drive extruder

description.text: This is a dual 40mm fan duct for my direct drive extruder, you can find here. Parts included in this design can be seen as white parts on the picture. Note: The hotend must be mounted with the heater facing the x carriage. The back part of the hotend is needed as a flow obstacle.

• 8x M3 nuts and 8x M3x10ish screws for the fans
  • 2x M3x16 screws to attach the fan ducts to the HotEndBracket
Simply print the parts, no support required. Attach the fan ducts to the HotendBracket with the 2 M3 screws and use the bracket as replacement for the original one.

title: Screw Adjustable Z Endstop Bracket for Prusa Mega

description.text:
This is a simple 2 piece bracket to adjust Z Axis height for the endstop.
  • No support material
  • 25% infill
  • Slower speed to acheive a nice vertical rod on P2
    • Needed Parts:
    2 - M3 x 20mm Screws
    1 - M3 x 40mm+ Screw (I prefer Allen Socket, but you could use any)
    3 - M3 nuts
    1 - Pusher Spring (I used a 5 mm pusher, but you could use a spring from a pen as well) You'll to attach the endstop pin to P2 in the desired orientation and the bracket to the desired location on the printer, then the long screw which you'll use to adjust the height in the middle of both parts, using the spring to provide resistance between the to parts.

author: smokinpuppy

description.text: 30mm Foldable Cube that is printed flat and then folded into shape. Prints fast and all the sides of the cube are smooth. Can be used to explore the properties of a platonic solid or can make an LED light. UPDATE: K12 Lesson ideas for this thing can be found at http://designmaketeach.com/2013/05/01/lesson-idea-the-3d-printed-foldable-cube/

30mm Foldable Cube that is printed flat and then folded into shape. Must be glued or taped to create a permanent cube. Use rubber bands to hold design together while glue is drying. Can be printed with or without infill. Examples were printed with PLA. The initial design consideration was to create a cube that had a smooth texture on all sides with accurate dimensions. Cubes printed as a single object on a hobby FDM printer can have a smooth bottom, layered sides and textured top. The foldable design ensures consistent, flat faces. An additional advantage is that the cube can be stored/transported flat then assembled later saving space. Students can use the Foldable Cube to explore the construction of a platonic solid. The Foldable Cube can be placed over a light source or an LED can be added to make a small cube light. Crude example of LED bulb taped to CR2032 battery is shown. Would like to increase the number of times the sides can be folded before it breaks. Current thickness of the folded edges are 0.2mm. Note for Printing on a Makerbot Replicator 2: The print must be oriented (rotated) on the build platform so the infill lines are as perpendicular as possible to the folds. If the infill lines are parallel to the folds the folds will crack. In an earlier version of Makerware the print could be rotated to the optimal 45 degree angle to create a hinges from the threads of plastic. New version of Makerware will cause the infill to run parallel to the folds at 45 degrees. We've had success rotating the print to approximately 30 degrees. Slic3r users have reported success with a concentric fill pattern. Original design created by DesignMakeTeach.com using FreeCAD.

description.text: In our archery club there are regular events for guests to try out shooting with a bow. Especially kids do handle the guest bows quite roughly sometimes and the sight pins are most of the time the first thing to hit the ground and break.

This is a replacement pin head that can be fitted to the left metal thread after removing the previous pin head. The diameter of the opening is a little smaller than the average pin diameter, it's designed to be glued on by heating up the metal pin and then melting it on directly.

author: moreno__r

description.text:
These corner brackets won't allow your build plate to slide around. Or become unlevel once the clamps are tightened. 8x M3x0.5-16lg screws and hex nuts are needed to complete a full set of corners. Corner parts:
Corner_brkt_v3 - Used when you have ThorLabs Fine Adjustment Screws installed.
Corner_brkt_v4 - Used with leveling shims, or use provision for installing an M3 set screw in the hole nearest the corner. Clip Parts:
F-300, A-300, F-305, A-305. The F parts are intended to be fastened and act as stops. put them on the back edge and one side of the build surface.
The A Parts have clearance that allows them to adjust to the edge of the build surface, and go on the sides opposite the F parts. 300 and 305 go with either 300 mm or 305 mm square build plates respectively. When tightening the A parts, only finger tight is needed. Two fingers on the shaft of the hex key is enough. Too tight can cause the build plate to bow. Even with finger tight, it can be necessary to loosen the screws to be able to remove the build plate. Misc: The text on the face of the A & F parts may not be really legible in the finished part. It depends on how much the first layer is squashed. If you need to deal with a build plate that isn't quite square.
1) Install A parts in place of F as needed.
2) Add shims between F parts and corner parts. (My personal preference)
3) Get the step files and mod them as needed.

I picked up the Adafruit USB microscope (http://www.adafruit.com/products/636 ) and the arm on it was pretty terrible. This replacement clamps onto the 7/16" diameter rod of my Panavise for easy inspection of boards. It is 5" long which gives it a lot of reach and is held together by 2 1/4-20 screws and nuts. There are hex slots in the bottom for nuts and I plan on making some knobs for the hex screws for adjustment. The plastic provides solid clamping friction but I can move the camera without undoing the screws.
Just print it out and assemble with 2 screws and nuts.

title: Improved DIY Low Cost FPV Goggles

description.text:
This is my improvement of the beautiful DIY Low Cost FPV Goggles by markvanhaze: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:583508
  • Modified mask piece by attaching these beautiful ski goggles: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:278294
  • The mask piece is now also smaller on the width as the ski goggles are already mounted. It can print on a 6 inch bed without splitting
  • Modified the center piece by attaching a remixed version of the male buckle of this sturdy Delta buckle so that it is possible to mount a top strap. You can get the female piece from here as that fits as the original: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:264185
  • The lense piece is unmodified so far, you can get it from the original by markvanhaze here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:583508
  • The monitor piece is unmodified so far, you can get it from the original by markvanhaze here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:583508

Tips for printing:
  • Use support when slicing the mask and center piece, because the ski goggles and male buckle piece does not touch the surface. The overhang would be too great for most printers.
  • 0.2 layer height and PLA. I'm sure ABS also works, but some pieces are quite large and may warp or crack unless your printing conditions and technique is good.
  • Print all pieces separately
    • The following extra needs to be bought (or equivalent):
  • 5 inch monitor 640x480, I bought this for discount at 19 USD, including shipping from China: http://www.aliexpress.com/item/Hot-selling-high-quality-tft-lcd-5-inch-Car-Monitor-Car-TV-Monitors-fit-for-car/32275602892.html . Marek also has a very nice screen with better resolution, although a bit more expensive: http://napolskimniebie.pl/index.php/sklep/wyposazenie-fpv/monitor-fpv-cyclope-eye-5-wersja-q-detail
  • 3x Fresnel lense, I got this one: http://www.aliexpress.com/item/Full-Page-XL-Magnifying-Sheet-Fresnel-Lens-3X-Magnification-Magnifier-17-x-26cm/32236994627.html
  • Sponge/rubber sealing, I got this: http://www.aliexpress.com/item/3mx15mmx7mm-self-adhesive-rectangular-EPDM-rubber-foam-sponge-cabinet-electrical-ark-box-sealing-strip/32257596345.html
  • 1x Headlamp or 3 straps. I got this one as it has a battery pack on the back that fits a 11.1 ZOP 1500mAh battery http://www.banggood.com/CREE-2000Lm-XM-L-XML-T6-LED-Adjustable-Headlight-Headlamp-p-908494.html
  • 1x 11.1v battery to drive the reciever and screen. I got this one as it fits well in the headlamp battery cover. http://www.banggood.com/ZOP-Power-11_1V-1500mAh-35C-Lipo-Battery-XT60-Plug-p-961321.html
    • Optional extras to be bought:
  • Shrinker tube for organized cables
  • Tape or preferrably glue for sticking the cables inside our outside the goggles. I used plastic strips to attach them on the side of the mask, but I'm sure it can be made more tidy by glueing them on the inside and shortening any excess of cable.
    • Mount it all together:
  • I also printed this little seal line strap for fastening the top strap on the other strap behind your head. Though it is not necessary if you buy a complete headlamp set like the one I did: Seal Line Strap: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:307347
  • Attach the 5 inch screen to the screen piece
  • Lead the cables where you want them. In this version there is no space on the inside due to the lens.
  • Glue the screen piece to the center piece
  • Cut something soft for the ski goggle face frame and glue it on. It could be for example foam or rubber sealing.
  • Glue the mask piece and center piece together
  • Attach head straps, I used one from a headlamp, but removed the lamp, took out the inside of the back battery pack cover. Fits a 1500mAh ZOP Power LiPo battery perfectly when all plastic excess inside is stripped away (if you're fine with having a LiPo strapped to the back of your head).

The spools that fit the Makerbot Replicator Mini are small and sometimes you want to hook up the machine to larger spools, but unfortunately these won't fit in the machine. Don´t worry, we got your back! We designed a spool-holder and a filament guide-tube-holder with a "snap-in" compartment for the universal dust filter (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:492067) to top things off. Both the spool-holder and filament-guide-tube-holder will snap in place on top of the MakerBot Mini plate. You can slide both parts left and right to best fit the spool size you want to use. To remove them, give them a push upwards and they should come off without any problems. You can use it together with the universal dust-filter or without, anything goes.

Please also see our Universal Cantilevered Spool Holder for 3D printers
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2297303

description.text:
Mounting bracket for the TOS FireWire Power Supply device that comes with the EGI EEG system (http://www.egi.com). Two FireWire cables are plugged into the device. This holder isolates the FireWire connections by moving the connections off the floor and onto the wall. The holder can be held to a wall using two strips of double stick tape. Developed by Graham Holt (https://www.linkedin.com/profile/view?id=32946354)
Laboratory of Cognitive Neuroscience (http://www.childrenshospital.org/research-and-innovation/research/labs/laboratories-of-cognitive-neuroscience)
Boston Children's Hospital (http://www.childrenshospital.org/). This object was modeled in FreeCAD (http://www.freecadweb.org/).

• Place two strips of double stick tape horizontally on the back of the holder.
  • Firmly affix holder to the wall using the double stick tape.
  • Insert TOS Firewire Adapter into the holder.

A pistol that can shoot NERF(TM) foam darts (amongst other things). Needs nothing other than some filament, 3 printed bits, 2 rubber bands and a foam dart.
It seems to generate more power than yer average foam dart gun, because I'm not bound by children's toys regulations. So, test it before using it in combat games.
It's parametric so you can change the grip size, dart dimensions and all sorts of stuff. No sights yet, and it could do with some clip on fancy grips, so hack away :)

Print. Knock the follower forward into the barrel and move it around a bit to clear fluff. Ream out any clogged pivot holes to 3mm. Use 2 short lengths of 3mm filament for the sear and trigger pivot points. Tuck a longer length of filament in the hole at the front of the handle until it pokes out the back. This is a spring to hold the sear in the "up" position. Melt filament pieces into place. DO NOT melt the spring to the sear. Fit two rubber bands, pull follower to the rear until it engages firmly with the sear. Poke a dart down the barrel, aim at something that doesn't care and squeeze the trigger firmly. If you do not have 3mm filament, here are printable pins and springs http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:43551 Assembly video here:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=auKLBw5P9bQ

Inspired by Iwo's Ducted cooling fan: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5756 The idea was to use a PC cooling fan and some printed ducting to make a printable hovercraft. Initially I choose a classic hovercraft design, fan at the back mainly for thrust with some air split from the flow and directed through some ducting to the skirt. Unfortunatly I couldnt get anywhere near enough air down the ducts supplying the skirt. Then after a discussion with a friend I came up with the current design. This has a single fan supplying only the skirt (I'll think about thrust when ive made this work), the geometry is such that the air passes almost straight into the skirt from the fan. This new design is able to achieve much higher air flow into the skirt area, though it still cannot provide enough pressure for the skirt to inflate and induce a hover-gap between it and the ground. I feel like I'm reaching the limit of what I can reasonably expect a cooling fan to do and will probably redesign this for use with a proper outrunner motor at some point. So I have posted this prototype design here so that others may try to make it work. This design is fully parametric and I have supplied the Inventor file.
Note: This was designed with an Educational copy of Inventor which imposes its own limitations upon how the design may be used.

• Print
  • Remove a PC cooling fan from its supports
  • Glue the cooling fan into the duct
  • Supply with 12v (i just plug it into the PSU on my pc when i need to test it)
    • Tip: I printed this with only 1 extra shell, with 2 extra shells the outer ring was printed hollow, and ended up as 2 individual cylinders which warped more easily.

comments.text: I also made a disposable plate / PC fan hovercraft.  It did not have propulsion, but you could send it gliding across the floor.  Some fans worked better than others.  Some plates worked better than others.  Some combinations did not work at all.  I seem to recall a larger plater working better than a smaller one.
comments.author: sgeos

comments.text: May I suggest you give the fan 18V rather than 12V.  I've found they stop working around 20V but start again once in the normal range.  Much more than 20V would kill it though =-X
comments.author: LightningPhil

comments.text: I think it would be good to increase the surface area you have under your skirt.  The up force should be equal to that area times the pressure difference.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Thanks for all the suggestions guys. Hopefully i will get some time to try them out in the next week or so
comments.author: brucedjones

comments.text: p.s. long ago when I was worked in a machine shop, I could glide a 3" x 2" block of steel across a granite "surface plate". A very thin layer of air would be trapped between both very flat surfaces providing the equivalent of an air bearing. This is a demonstration of the importance of a perfectly flat bottom on your hover craft skirt.
comments.author: tc_fea

comments.text: as brianorca mentioned you need a much larger pressure area under the skirt to to provide sufficient lift. also a bit more height on the skirt (at least near the fan) since all that air has to get from the fan out to the edges of the skirt. finally test on a very flat surface with a very flat lower edge on the skirt. This is allows the leakage gap at the edge of the skirt to be very small and allow a maximum pressure in the skirt plenum.  :)
comments.author: tc_fea

comments.text: I think you might need a larger skirt area. The fan will produce a very small differential pressure, maybe a few grams per square inch, so you have to spread that pressure over a large area. CFM is a factor too, as mentioned above, but you're not at that limit yet.
comments.author: brianorca

comments.text: Did a little research, and it seems like you need at least 4 square feet per pound of mass. (For a typical PC fan, which might push only 1.5mmH2O or 0.002 PSI)
comments.author: brianorca

comments.text: Its a Maplin own brand fan so I dont imagine the spec sheet is enitrly accurate. But its apparently 44 +- 10% CFM and 4.54 Inch-H20 Max Pressure (what on earth kind of a unit is Inch-H20).
comments.author: brianorca

comments.text: I don't think you've hit the fan's CFM limit, we used to do this with a cooling fan and a styrofoam plate.   On your design I'm trying to figure out what the portion in the center of the duct is, because it might be blocking or reducing air flow.  Every time the air has to change direction it looses huge amounts of energy.
comments.author: Mike77

comments.text: The curved bit was just to send some of the air outwards so it hits the skirt wall, not sure if this is required. For the most part the middle bit is there because directly behind the middle of the fan I wouldnt expect any air flow, though I may be wrong.
comments.author: Mike77

description.text: This is not an exact copy, nor is it legal to use non-BSA wheels for competition. This was "ceremonial" wheel we gave to the cubs instead of a participation ribbon. It will fit a car, and we encouraged the cubs to put it on their car after the race so in future years they would know when the car was built. You can see details about the car at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:735561, and the driver at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:726447.

This was created with OpenScad. The script is provide so you can modify it. There is a plain wheel, and one with text added. I used Inkscape to create the circular text (you need to convert objects to path), and then used Tinkercad to join them (see https://tinkercad.com/things/iQb4edo033e).

description.text: Nozzle for introducing gas to a burner, will need to drill holes for air to enter into the bubbled piece

Don't take
a curve
at 60 per.
We hate to lose
a customer
Burma-Shave (1939) The first time I saw the iconic Burma-Shave signs was at my favorite bizarre tourist attraction in Wisconsin, The House on the Rock. Wikipedia has a pretty good description of the signs: "Burma-Shave was an American brand of brushless shaving cream, famous for its advertising gimmick of posting humorous rhyming poems on small sequential highway roadside signs." I wanted to turn these classic signs into a desk accessory/decoration, not wanting to stifle anyone's creativity I've made it so you can enter your own five line rhyming poem (or pick a classic Burma-Shave poem from the end of this post!) to make your own desktop signs. This can be printed with using a dual extruder printer or a single extruder printer with a filament swap. All files will be exported via Customizer at once.

Hardly a driver / Is now alive / Who passed / On hills / At 75 / Burma-Shave
Past / Schoolhouses / Take it slow / Let the little / Shavers grow / Burma-Shave
If you dislike / Big traffic fines / Slow down / Till you / Can read these signs / Burma-Shave
Don't take / a curve / at 60 per. / We hate to lose / a customer / Burma-Shave

the 6 on one is a nice way to condense it to one print though.

title: Airsoft - Wingun Revolver 6x6 BB multi casing

description.text:
A multishot casing designed for wingun-style airsoft revolver.
The shells are connected at the base for faster reloads (+less likely to get lost).
Each shell can hold max. 6bbs and may also fit similar airsoft revolvers like umarex, cybergun,...
It was tested with PLA and ABS. Both worked but I prefered ABS because it was more flexible. Attention: You may have to rescale the object! It was designed in mm (1 inch = 25,4mm)!

comments.text: Do you think you could design one for 4.5mm bb's? Thanks!

5th attempt at a cable mount. (drawn in sketchup, cleaned with netfabb) I had problems with the clip being too brittle and tried to fix it by fattening the clip. Didn't work? Maybe I need to change some slic3r setting? This is supposed to hold the '3/8" Flex Tubing' cable sleeve I got from Home Depot (part# FLX-3810T). The bottom foot should mount on the ord-bot hadron x carrage using the 2 holes on the upper right side of the carriage plate.

I finally got #5 to print as a usable part. Previous prints were too brittle.  I used 1.75mm white ABS (measured 1.60-1.63) and set slic3r to use 120% extrusion.  (Previous parts had linear voids at fracture points.)  
Tested this against the Tubing Sleeve and it is a tight fit. Once I mount it on the printer I'll post a picture showing the fit.
